title: Catalyzing Change: Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion in a Global Perspective
segmentation: My name is Aryan Colingo.
I just recently graduated from Harvard.

I studied international education policy and obtained my Masters in May and now I'm serving as a teaching fellow for the sensor for Asia leadership in Malaysia, and I'm teaching a Harvard Business School course.
Um?
So the course or the project that I.
Came up with is catalyzing change, diversity, equity and inclusion in a global perspective, and I wouldn't have been able to complete this project without my mentors.
So Larry is one of them.
He's right here and he served as the associate Dean for open education at the University of California, Irvine, and my other mentor Nasir Baba from Nigeria.
He wasn't able to make it this week, but he he serves as the male youth specialist for them.
A fee to northern Nigerian skills.
Development program, so I provided 2 links.
Everything is on a Google Drive but also everything is also put into canvas and I can show you a preview of this in a little bit so.
I'll tell you guys a brief story about how I got into this whole topic.

Back in high school, about 10 years ago I attended high school in Marin County, California and I was one of three Asians at my whole high school, so I experienced racism every day, and I was walking home one time and a group of my classmates, a group of boys were following me and one of them through a Chinese chicken salad at my head, and he said a racial slur to me after that as well.
So after reflecting upon that experience, you know I was quiet.
I kept to myself and I realize that.
The way to fight ignorance is through education.
And so I became interested in education an.
I promised myself that in college I would be involved in, you know, the Office of Student Affairs or the Office of Diversity.
And I became a diversity facilitator, facilitating dialogues on topics surrounding diversity, equity and inclusion.
So this is what I'm sorry, thank you.
So this is what the whole.
Course is about it's geared towards college students and I want them to be able to be encouraged to facilitate dialogues on these topics.
The course addresses emerging diversity and inclusion issues, and a big part of the course is self reflection.
So reflecting upon your own identity's and privileges and seeing how these experiences compared to those who fit, who faced systematic barriers, parts four and five.

Of my course are teaching them how to facilitate intergroup dialogue, so teaching facilitation tools and by the end of the course, I hope that they'll be encouraged to bring what they learn to their communities.
To facilitate these dialogues.
And I hope that they'll also gain intercultural skills.
So the target audience is college students.
When I was developing the course, I was picturing incoming freshmen who would take this course as part of their orientation.
It could potentially be taught to high school students, but I think maybe the concepts introduced are sort of complex.

And I was also thinking maybe working professionals in higher education, so when I was at Harvard, I realized that some of my professors were a little bit culturally insensitive and when I talked to the academic Dean, I learned that the professors don't are not required to take any sort of diversity training, so I want to pitch the idea of professors taking some sort of diversity training, or.
Workshop and I think that my course could potentially serve as a good resource for them.

Third Point, I put those with an interest in diversity, equity and inclusion issues, but I kind of take that back because I want to push people who are not interested in diversity, equity and inclusion to also take this course.
And you know to try and challenge their beliefs.
When I applied for this opportunity, I had put down goals for 10 and 16, but I think that goal 16 is the one that really deals with what my course is all about.
So Goal 16 is promoting just peaceful and inclusive societies an my course is all about cultivating and installing people with respect for others, regardless of difference.
My course consists of five modules and I'll give a brief overview of each one.
Each module is designed to be 80 minutes, so a total of 400 minutes over all module one is self identity and intersectionality.
So in this module we explore the different domains of self identity, sexual orientation, race, gender, socioeconomic status, language, etc, and how these all intersect and interact with one another.
The second module is understanding privilege and oppression, so I first start with defining what privilege and what oppression is.
And then I delve deeper into the four types of oppression, ideological oppression, institutional oppression, internalized oppression, an interpersonal oppression.
The third is cultural appropriation, which I learned is not really a thing.
It's not really a thing outside of the US, So does everyone know what cultural appropriation is, or, OK, I can define it really quickly.
It's basically when a privileged group takes elements of an oppressed or privileged, when it's it's when a privileged or dominant group takes elements of an oppressed or subordinate group.
And claims it as their own without giving them recognition.
So I'll give you an example.
Cinco de Mayo in the United States is celebrated a lot by my fraternity.
You know they're not really my friends 'cause they were bullies to me.
But in fraternities, in the US they like to celebrate Cinco de Mayo, which is from Mexico, and they take elements of Mexican culture like sombreros and tequila and other elements of Mexican culture.
And they use it in their parties, but they don't really know what Cinco de Mayo is about.
They don't know the culture of Mexico, like when I ask them, what do you think Cinco de Mayo is about?
They think it's the Mexican Independence Day, but actually Mexican Independence Day is not the 5th of May.
It's September 16th and they don't know that.
So cultural appropriation through this module I want them to see or reflect upon if they're appropriating other cultures and how.
They can respect other cultures.
The 4th and 5th modules is facilitating dialogue, so I'm teaching them tools to facilitate intergroup dialogues.
I'm also teaching them how to ask the right questions.
What are appropriate questions and what are inappropriate questions, and then in the 5th module, I summarize all of the five different modules.

So I really didn't know a lot about O ER coming into this and I really found out about O ER through Larry, so I used Microsoft PowerPoint to develop the five different modules and then eventually I converted it into PDF files which are all on canvas.
Every module comes with a workbook, so there's a corresponding workbook in Microsoft Word, and these include definitions from.
Each module that are key definitions as well as different exercises that the students can do, and everything is also on canvas, so I can show you a preview of.
Where is the @ this is?
Sorry.
I found it.
Sorry, where's the_sign?
The Slovenian keyboard is different.
_ crosscultural OK. Um, so there's supposed to be a picture.
Oh, there it is.
So this is the homepage of the Canvas site.
And then all the modules are under pages.
So, so the home page has like a brief description of what the course is about, and then it briefly mentions the five modules.
And it gives recognition to Nasir and Larry, of course.
And then all the modules are.
Here and so if you click on each one.
Um?
You'll get like the materials for each module, so.

This is for example, the first one I want to make it so it's easier to navigate, so that's one of my next steps, but all the modules are uploaded on Canvas, and then there's also a Google drive with everything so far.
Um?
So the format is basically how I formatted this presentation.
And these exercises are also included in Microsoft Word in the workbooks.
So in terms of the resources I used to find O ER materials, Larry taught me everything, but I know about, oh, we are, which is still limited and I'm still trying to learn more.
I'm sorry, I think someone was taking OK.
Larry was the one who really helped me with ovr materials, so everything that I had to ask about Ovr I went to Larry and he taught me.
You know what sites to go to for pictures or videos.
He really helped me with that.
And then Nasir was the one who provided feedback on the actual content of my project and he was very detailed.
If I put an extra or extra a he would mark what does this mean?
You know this is not necessary here so he was very detailed and giving me feedback and.
I'm still trying to get feedback also from my mentors at Harvard and at Georgetown.
Main challenges I faced some difficulty finding good O ER materials on diversity, equity and inclusion.

Another challenge was finding a common time to Skype because Larry's from California Nasir is from Nigeria and I'm from Boston or I was in Boston at the time so I had this doodle poll where everyone would check when they're available and only like one was available for everyone.
Connection issues on Skype was another issue.
And then like what Greg and Jenny mentioned, time management was a big issue for me.
I undertook this project when I was a full time student at Harvard and I realized that this takes a lot of work and it's not something that you know you could wait till last minute.
So I had a period of time when I really just focused on this.
Again, I'm I'm still learning a lot about O ER.
I'm a newbie in this field of education, so I'd love to participate again if this happens again next year in terms of what else I would like to do.
I didn't list it here, but I'd like to add videos to make it more interactive.
I also want to make the canvas site easier to navigate and nor told me about this one program.
I think Canva.
So I want to see what that's about.
I'm also pitching my idea to Harvard and Georgetown.
Again, I think that it would be useful for professors to maybe take the course I want to try and do a pilot run with some of my colleagues and friends back home.
And of course, I'd like to get your input so I will give you the website later on.
And then my suggestions for your team.
I would consider scheduling more frequent video calls between.
You know the team, the author and the mentors, and then maybe consider keeping time different time zone differences in mind.
Thank you.
